sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Does your little raſcally ſoul conceive I'd let a friend ſuffer for an act of benevolence, and to myſelf? No! human laws may puniſh other crimes; but, let the hotteſt bolt of heaven ſtrike ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Timolin. (without)
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Conſtable, 'pon my ſalvation I didn't—

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.p: Meaſter, here bes an accompliſh.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: I'm not accompliſh'd, I'm quite a bog trotter.

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.p: The picture that was robb'd out of—

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: What, you found it upon him?

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.p: Upon his very head.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: You notorious criminal!

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: My maſter to be jumping about with Ladies, and leave me—oh! my dear Sir! (runs to Lord Arthur. Tradeſman whiſpers. Timolin pointing to Sir Hans) did he! then plaiſe your honour, will you be bound bail for me too?

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: For you! pardon me.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: No, Sir! aſk them to pardon me.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: I'll bail my ſervant.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: You! a rare ſhadow! ah! friend, I know you. Thanks to the noble Lord Torrendel's gallantries, we've twenty ſuch Lords cutting cabbages, and drudging for oyſters down at Sandgate Iſland—but becauſe your mother had a pretty face, a great fortune, and no virtue—

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Throw a reflection on the memory of my honour'd parent! defame the ſacred memory of the dead—the only univerſal epitaph—oblivion to the frailties of humanity!— I'll murder him, by heavens!

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: No occaſion to ſwear, you've ſaid it, and you'll do it.

sp.speaker: Sir Han.
sp.p: Hold! the devil's in you; break the peace, and I loſe my two thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: True, my dear friend—oh! I burn with fury—but your Worſhip's wig ca'n't ſwear a battery. (twirls it) There's Burn's Juſtice, Blackſtone, and Coke upon Littleton. (knocks tables about) Come along, Timolin.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Maſter, ſtay for me—take me—

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Oh! what a bright model for my ſon George!

div.head: SCENE I.—An antique Room in the Caſtle.
div.stage: Enter Conſtable, and L'OEILLET, puſhing in TIMOLIN.

sp.speaker: Loeillet.
sp.p: There, you ſtay faſt, coquin! ſuch audace—of robbery, take ſurniture and pictures out of my Lor's houſe!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'm more guilty than my maſter, as the receiver is worſe than the thief.

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.p: Who is your maſter, the receiver? ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Friend, you may take me for a robber, if you will; but you ſhan't prove me an informer, becauſe I've a regard for my character.

sp.speaker: Loeillet.
sp.p: Stay there till we find Mr. Dickin, de juſtice, to ſend you to jail; be merry with that table and chair; ſorry to diſgrace—make a brown bear of my chamber—there ſit and ſing —"de charge is prepared, de lawyers are met."

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p:
I wiſh they had crammed me into a jail at once, and not took me up in this diſmal top of a caſtle. Oh did my poor mother ever think that, before I died, I ſhould get myſelf hanged for a thief? Lord Arthur! Lord Arthur! unlucky was the day that Mr. Felix Timolin hired to be your ſervant man. (looking at the table) Here's letters and papers, ſcribble ſcrabble, eh! why, this is my Lord's own hand, I remember it by one of his Franks— To
Monſieur Loeillet, what does he write to his ſervants; but what's all this to me; no way to get out of window, may be in this cloſet.

div.stage: Enter, at a ſecret door, LADY TORRENDEL, and MARTHA.

sp.speaker: Martha. (ſurpriſed)
sp.p: Why, I vow my Lady, this is the valet's room, and none of us ever knew this door to it.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: I think, Martha, I remember the caſtle better than you, who have lived in it ſo long. Out of that door there's a ſtair-caſe to my Lord's dreſſing-room, where I'll wait till he comes in. I'd wiſh to know a little more before I ſee him. Rather mean this lurking about and tampering with ſervants—but no hope of reclaiming him, except he's certain I know what then will be out of his power to deny. (aſide) My Lord rode out you ſay; formed diſcompoſed? well, not a word that I'm here, (Martha returns) this houſe ſeems all wild, no regularity, peace, or the comforts of a home, but the gratification of paſſions which reaſon and nature now ſhould ſubdue, reconciles him to inquietude, meanneſs, and diſhonour. So, this room now belongs to his vile agent! it was formerly put to a better purpoſe—this is the very room I converted to a ſchool for the poor infant ruſtics. Here the young mind was trained to virtue and induſtry—here now, are perhaps, plans laid to corrupt and deſtroy the ſweet roſe of innocence! Eh, who's here!

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: No, looks into a deep court. Oh, I'm very high up, they've double locked the door. (trying it) Oh dear! oh dear!

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: Dos'nt ſeem to be one of the family!

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: This letter, from my Lord to Monſieur, I've a ſtrong curioſity to ſee.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: How! as I'm here on a voyage of diſcovery, the ſight of that might prepare me better for this dreaded interview with my Lord.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: It's ungenerous to look into another man's letter, only I'd like to ſee the raſtieſt mode of writing. I'm told its not the faſhion now to croſs the t's, and put little tittles on the i's; no harm to ſee that ſure— (reads) The ſight of this boy has troubled me exceedingly!— Boy! oh, that's my maſter; (reading) Probably, I ſhan't be home before evening, but if you can contrive to get Auguſta into your power, the better. She may be brought down to Sandgate iſland—Oh, here's villainy!

sp.speaker: Lady Tor. (aſide)
sp.p: Some poor intended victim! My coming at ſuch a time is highly fortunate.

sp.speaker: Timolin (reads).
sp.p:
Pray have an eye upon that Arthur's ill-looking Iriſhman—Oh, that crowns his rogueries— No harm to keep Auguſta under lock and key. I'll keep this proof of their wickedneſs, and if they talk of hanging me for a bit of an old picture, I'll bring it out in the noſe of their ſhabby red faces— ill looking Iriſhman—eh, one would think they took me for Miſs Auguſta. (ſees Lady Tor.)
Then they have locked you up? you moſt unhappy beautiful ſoul.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: Why he takes me for the preſent object of purſuit! by giving into this miſtake, I may diſcover ſome more of my huſband's atchievements. (aſide) Are you his Lordſhip's emiſſary?

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: I, Miſs! I deſpiſe ſuch doings.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: I believe it; your ſace ſpeaks honeſty.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Then it ſpeaks truth, and the devil himſelf ſhan't make it tell a lie.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: But, who are you?

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: My maſter is his Lordſhip's ſon that's at this inſtant ſhifting about, and can't get a beef-ſteak without venturing his neck for it.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: True—Martha told me of this unhappy deſtitute youth—Oh, huſband! falſe to me, and unnaturally cruel to the offspring of your follies.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Miſs, I'll aſſure you, Lord Arthur is as brave a little boy—

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: And bears his forlorn ſtate with meekneſs and reſignation?

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Oh yes! Miſs, he's as meek and gentle—ah, hem!

sp.speaker: Lady Tor. (aſide).
sp.p: Poor youth, he has a father, and yet an orphan! Then he ſhall find a friend in me—though not mine, he belongs to the man I ſtill love! but to continue this deception—cou'd you contrive any means for me to fly this manſion of ſhame and ruin?

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p:
Offer to come in to touch her, and,
by the mighty powers of heaven, I'll ſlay you.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: Oh!
sp.stage: (runs in. The door's burſt open, and enter Lord Arthur.)

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Suffer me to periſh, and impriſon my faithful ſquire for his attachment! Put your arms a-kimbo, ſirrah, ſtump down thoſe great ſtairs with your hat on, and let me ſee who dares ſquint at you—Oh! that lovely divine Auguſta!

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: What! then you've ſeen her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: What do you ſtand winking and making faces there, ſirrah? come out.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: But there's ſomebody elſe lock'd up.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Kick up your legs boldly, no matter whoſe ſhins are in the way.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: B'y'r leave there for Mr. Felix Timolin.

div.head: SCENE II. A Street.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Aye! and well George?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: We had a dance, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: As if he had ſaid we had a funeral. 'Sblood! man, ſay—we had a dance. (capers) Arthur was maſter of the ceremonies—you ſhuffled it away? eh, boy?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I was'nt afraid to ſhuffle, for I had my thick walking ſhoes on.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Shoes! aſſes' hoofs! I believe they're half an inch thick.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, they're an inch. (aſide) I muſt ſee if the poor woman has releaſed her huſband.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: George, ſo 'twas you raſp'd up the fiddle for them?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ſo we had no fiddler to pay.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Pſha! I'd hire Handel's anniverſary band to ſee you dance the Cameronian Rant with Auguſta. This ſcheme of leaving her at large wo'nt do—ſhe'll be ſnapt up. Gad, yonder ſhe is—I muſt clench this buſineſs. Why do you put on that diſmal look, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I was thinking, father, of the cruelty in keeping people in priſon for ſmall debts above a twelvemonth however; liberty's ſo ſweet, they'd purchaſe it if in their power, if not, hard to puniſh a man for only being unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Here comes Miſs Auguſta. Devil's in your thick ſoal'd ſhoes!

sp.speaker: Auguſla.
sp.p: That man certainly whiſpered ſomething diſagreeable that cauſed the abrupt departure of Lord Arthur.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Dear no, he's a very civil ſoul, why 'twas papa's conſtable. Oh my good gracious, if here is'nt George.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p:
Your waiſtcoat's buttoned all crooked —no powder in your hair—by the lord! you look like the duſtman. (apart) Well Miſs, how do
you like your new ſituation?—ſtop, I want to ſpeak to you.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Stop, he wants to ſpeak to us—how do you do, George?

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Ha! very free with George! (aſide) Miſs Woodbine, I've your good at heart. Your uncle's whim, in taking his fortune from you, makes you an object of compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: Many would rather be an object of envy—but, to my thinking, an humble ſtate is preferable to affluence, built upon the ruins of unmerited adverſity.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans. (aſide)
sp.p: Made for each other! (apart) George, to her in her own way—out with your handkerchief, and cry for the poor debtors. My ſon, Miſs, is ſo happy to ſee—to be with you—

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Happy to ſee her? but I'm ſure its no ſuch thing, old codger.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: He expreſſed great joy at your coming ſo opportunely.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Opportunely indeed! (looking at his ſtockings) Miſs, could you lend me a needle and thread?

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Go along you raſcal, ſortune! I'll bind you apprentice to a taylor.

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: You're happy, Sir, in having a ſon of ſo much frugality for his years.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Frugal, ma'am! he's the moſt extravagant—

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I ſee now he only wants them to like each other; I muſt prevent this.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p:
Why, look now, with his coat over his knuckles; he has on lace ruffles at three guineas a pair. Pull down your ruffles. (pulls George's wriſtbands down) By the lord! he has got into
hopſack. What have you done with all the fine linen and lace I ſent you?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: The lace was too fine for uſe—but the Holland made ſoft child-bed linen for the curate's wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Yes, madam, the biſhop's lady was the good woman in the ſtraw. He is very frolickſome—it's a ſhame for you to be ſuch a buck.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Lord, Miſs, George is no buck! he's a mere milk ſop, an't you George?

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Get away you little devil, who wants your prate. (apart) Miſs, we'll conceal your loſs from my ſon—he's ſo proud—ſee how he throws his head about. (apart) George, with Auguſta's caſh, you can do ſuch pretty charities! Son, this lady is worth one hundred thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Lord, how can you tell ſuch fibs— George, ſhe's only my governeſs, and as poor —borrowed five ſhillings from me juſt now to releaſe her box from the waggon—ſay you did.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Get along you little buſy thing (apart). You know, ma'am, you're an immenſe fortune.

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: Sir, I am neither ambitious of compaſſion or ridicule.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: George, never mind—ſhe's very rich.

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: Oh no, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Zounds! Madam, you're a Jew.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: My governeſs is not a Jew, ſhe has more religion than the biſhop.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p:
The devil's in me, if I don't make your father pull your ears! (apart) Miſs, my
ſon has a moſt liberal mind, a ſoul of magniſicent extravagance.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Madam, my father is only jeſting.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: True, George, now that's very good, Sir Hans is always making his ſun of every body.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: By the Lord, overthrowing my whole ſcheme. (aſide) Hop home you little magpie.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Madam, be aſſured, I eſteem oeconomy the firſt virtue.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Then the devil's in you both! but it's you, prating monkey, has done it all; you, you raſcal, with your oeconomy and aſſes' hooſs, truff down to Samphire Hall; and you, Miſs, ſtalk with your poverty to Mr. Dickins, the banker's.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Madam, your humble ſervant!

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Devil's in your humble ſervant, you civil ſcoundrel! ſome mad gander will tuck her and her fortune under his wing, and hop off to Gretna Green.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: George ſent down to the rocks, oh! oh! then I know where ſomebody will go. (aſide) Sir Hans, your moſt obedient, good morning to you, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Oh very polite Ma'am, but I wiſh you had dropt your curtſy half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Auguſta. (looking out)
sp.p: The forlorn thoughtleſs Arthur! Sir, tell me—is Miſs Woodbine's ſon my uncle's heir? then why not inſtantly extricate him, from the embarraſſing perplexities that muſt end in his deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p:
What ſon? (looking out) The gay Arthur! true, Lord Torrendel's; (aſide) oh ho!
I ſuſpect there's love here—this was her dancing partner. My dear, as to affection and all that, this Arthur—

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: Sir, I am only intereſted for him, on account of my couſin Woodbine.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Right! for his heart is engaged to a girl, he told me all over a glaſs of hock. (Auguſta agitated) (aſide) Yes! ſhe likes him— then, in one word, Miſs Auguſta, my dear, I'll not part with you, till I ſee you and my ſon fairly coupled.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur. (without)
sp.p: Sir Hans!

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Yes, Sir! paſt three.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Paſt three! Don't much like his avoiding me, and taking the lady. His bailbond may keep me from limbo—but muſtn't rob me of paradiſe either.

div.p: Run, ſirrah, after Miſs Auguſta, and—

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Back again to your father's?

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: You will perſiſt, we left Miſs Auguſta there; (takes a bit of paper, and writes with pencil) if I can but obtain the love of this charming girl, ſhe's ſo beautiful, elegant—but then, very modeſt; I'll have her—oh! Timolin, I will have her, run with this letter.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: With what?

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Stop to aſk queſtions with your hows and whats—run, take this letter to the young lady.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p:
Oh! I'll give no letters to ladies. Do you want, Sir, to carry on your father's profligate rigmarolds? but you don't make a French
Mounſeer of me—for the ſpirit of Mr. Felix Timolin is a peg above that, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: What! walk back, if you pleaſe, into Caſtle Quad.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Then 'pon my word, I won't.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: How, you ſcoundrel! do you object to go into priſon when I—? begone! I diſcharge you.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, I diſcharge myſelf, and there's a receipt for my wages. (ſnaps his fingers) I'd hazard my life, to procure you what you might again repay—but, helping you to take the innocence you could never return, is beneath the ſoul of Mr. Felix Timolin.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Dem it! now I've loſt him. I had no conception of this mighty Iriſh honour of his brave ſoul. He has had moral, from his ruſtic parent in his mud cabin; but, I never knew a father's kind precept or good example.

div.stage: Enter COACHMAN, ſurveys LORD ARTHUR at a diſtance.
div.p: What does this fellow eye me for?

sp.speaker: Coachman.
sp.p: My Lady ſent me to know his perſon—yes! that's he, very well.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: You're no Coachman, my friend you're a bailiff—they take all diſguiſes.

div.head: SCENE III. A walk near Lord Torrendel's

sp.speaker: L'Oeillet.
sp.p:
To divert mi Lor from de thought of dis tapageur, ſon of his, I muſt get off Miſs
Auguſta for him; but, to ſee more of this letter of inſtruction—eh! oh! I have left it on the table in my room—Thomas have borrow Sir Hans's livery to carry her ſham meſſage; but if there be danger, we yet want ſome ſtrong, able, deſperate—

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: I could be contented with one dinner in three days, becauſe it's a thing I've practis'd with ſome ſucceſs—but, my poor dear maſter—

sp.speaker: L'Oeillet.
sp.p: Oh! you be got out, where I did lock you—

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Here, lock me up again; for I've loſt my maſter, and I don't care how I am.

sp.speaker: L'Oeillet.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you be not overcharg'd vid money, and I take it you be fripon—in your character, roguery be the leading feature.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: I judge that your noſe is your leading feature—ſo I take it. (advancing) I, a rogue! produce a proof that I'm one.

sp.speaker: L'Oeillet.
sp.p: Here be a ſtirling proof.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: So, becauſe you've money, you've a right to call a poor man out of his name.

sp.speaker: L'Oeillet. (gives it)
sp.p: Dere now, call me out of my name.

sp.speaker: Timolin. (looking at it)
sp.p: Then, you're an honeſt man a genteel noble lad. If I can find my lord, this will carry us back to town.

sp.speaker: L'Oeillet.
sp.p:
Arreté! dat is for ſervice you vill do me. (looking out) Milor! go! dat footman vill tell you vat it be. Beſides, more reward,
if you ſhould be taken up again for little peccadilloz, milor's intereſt vill releaſe you. Allez!

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Paid for doing good before hand! now I've gold and a clear conſcience, two companions that are ſeldom together now a day's.

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: That fellow of Arthur's ſtill lurking about here!

sp.speaker: L'Oeillet.
sp.p: Peſte! quelle ballourdiſe! I have made fine confident in my Lord's ſcheme, (aſide) O! my Lord, he only aſk—

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: I hope you have'n't let this affair go further than thoſe already concerned?

sp.speaker: L'Oeillet.
sp.p: Oh! no, my Lord! if he knew I had employed this Iriſhman, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: L'Oeillet, I've improved upon your plan. Thomas's being in Sir Hans's livery may not be ſufficient to perſuade Auguſta, that ſhe is really ſent for by him—now if you could borrow Sir Hans's poſt chaiſe, that would effectually remove ſuſpicion—make any excuſe, he'll be glad to oblige me.

sp.speaker: L'Oeillet.
sp.p: Diantre! here I go for Sir Hans's coach to carry off Miſs Auguſta, and have ſet Thomas and the Iriſhman to take her off with horſes.

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: Why, L'Oeillet, you don't ſeem over hearty in the cauſe now?

sp.speaker: L'Oeillet.
sp.p: Oh! I'm devoted to your Lordſhip's ſervice.

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: Once wheedled into the carriage, a pretext is ſoon found to get her to Sandgate Iſland.

sp.speaker: L'Oeillet.
sp.p: Ah! mais ceſt que ceſt excellent ca!

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: About it now—I ſhall be there before you.

sp.speaker: L'Oeillet.
sp.p: Pardi! dis is lucky—for now I vill do it myſelf. I viſh tho' I cou'd meet vid dis maroufle, to hinder him meddle in de affair— dat malheureux Iriſh tief vill do me ſome miſchief.

div.head: SCENE IV.—A Road.
div.stage: Enter TIMOLIN, and THOMAS, in Sir Hans's Livery.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Thomas, I know all your plan, now you've told me. So here you've borrowed Sir Hans's livery from one of his ſervants, and you're to go and tell Miſs Auguſta, he has ſent you for her—but, as you may be a cowardly kind of chap, the Mounſeer has bid me aſſiſt you with my tight bit of arm. Huſh! here ſhe comes

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: I thought ſhe was a little girl juſt left ſchool.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: I don't know, whether ſhe ſhe goes to ſchool or no—but, this is the very Miſs Auguſta, that was lock'd up in the caſtle with me. (aſide) Oh! I'll make a neat example of ye all.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p:
My mind is in a ſtate of the moſt tormenting ſolicitude! I wiſh I knew where to find
this young lady, and apprize her of my Lord's deſigns. Whether to return and wait for him? I dread the interview, unkind upbraiding often ſhakes the very baſis of affection. Yet I know he'll endeavour, by ſome artful evaſion, to ſlip from my charge, except I can bring it to a full conviction—but firſt to afford this poor young man aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Young man, that muſt be me—ſhe ſaw I was in diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: Deliver this to him, without leting him know who it comes from.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Stop! I'm here.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: Oh, his ſervant.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Now, this goodneſs to me, has determined me, in what I was reſolved upon; to ſave her from all danger.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: Perhaps I may now learn, who this young lady is.

sp.speaker: Timolin. (To Thomas)
sp.p: Go you, and ſtay with your horſes—I'll deliver the meſſage to her myſelf.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: But you're not in Sir Hans's livery —It wo'n't take her.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: How d'ye do, Miſs Auguſta?

sp.speaker: Lady Tor. (aſide)
sp.p: My truſty champion's miſtaking me for her, I find, continues.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Miſs, your guardian, Sir Hans Burgeſs, hopes for your company down at Samphire-Hall—he has ſent horſes.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: I'll whiſper a few words, that ſhall bring her directly. Harkye, Miſs! don't go, this is a rogue, that wants to coax you again into the mouſe-trap.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: You miſtake—I'm not the perſon.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: That's a good thought to deny yourſelf —I'll ſecond it—are you ſure you never ſaw Miſs Auguſta before now?

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Then this is not ſhe—ſo go about your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: He wants to inveigle you, to Lord Torrendel.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: Indeed! this is charming, as I ſuppoſed! the moſt lucky opportunity to do good, prevent evil, ſave the innocent from ruin, and overwhelm the guilty in the bluſhing ſhame of his own baſe intentions. (aſide) I was apprehenſive of ſome error—you've brought horſes you ſay—very well, I'll—wait on my guardian.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Then you are Miſs Auguſta. Why, what did you mean juſt now by—

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you're right enough.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: If they take you for a Lady, that will fly off to an old libertine, they're right enough indeed; but I was wrong, when I thought you a bit of an angel.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: Come.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: A word, ma'am! your charitable intentions juſt now about me, were good—but, ſince you give yourſelf up to this old reprobate, I ſcorn your aſſiſtance, and, if a little turn of virtue, ſhould ever make you repent of your nonſenſe, don't expect any defence from the ſoul of Mr. Felix Timolin.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p:
Heavens! I leave a ſhocking impreſſion on the mind of this worthy creature. (aſide)
Well, well, we ſhall find time to clear my character.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: An old rotten potatoe for your character! bye and bye, when you're ſeen flouriſhing in curricles, with a different gallant every day, ſtuck up at your elbow, you'll ſtill be chattering about your character, to all the turnpike-men.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Yes! it is a baliſſ—he's at my heels. Timolin, do you ſee any door open? ſtand in that ſpot, you ſcoundrel.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Oh! if any more of thoſe compliments paſs between you and me, it's a toſs up who's to pay them.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: If he don't touch me, it's no caption.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: He's returning with the money, the gay miſs gave him for me.

sp.speaker: Coachman.
sp.p: I've had a good chace after you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Attempt to give me the tip, and—

sp.speaker: Coachman. (taking papers from his pocket)
sp.p: Here it is—this bill for three hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: If it was ten thouſand, I wou'dn't accept it.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: You villain, do I want you to accept bills for me?

sp.speaker: Coachman.
sp.p: It's a good note, and your own too.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p:
Well, I know I have notes and
bonds enough out—but if I pay one of them, I'll be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Sir, don't frighten yourſelf, about what doesn't concern you.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, ſirrah; of my own accord, I came from our dance, when old Wighum, the juſtice, ſent for me; but, compell'd, I will not go; ſo let the plaintiff carry the bills in to my father.

sp.speaker: Coachman.
sp.p: Now, Sir, you're too nice. I promiſed to do the buſineſs, and I will.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Aye! he only wants to touch me.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Arrah! what ſignifies your dancing round me, like a couple of May-poles?

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Oh, how my fingers—Timolin, knock him down—I wonder whether it's a capture if I touch him.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: What are you at with your caps, and hats? The Engliſh of he thing is—Miſs Auguſta, I deſpiſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Speak o of my divine charmer.

div.stage: Strikes him, and runs off, Coachman after.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Oh! if he diſcharges me, and comes once a day to give me a knock in my cheek, I'm to have a bleſſed life of it—tho' my honour wou'd not ſuffer me to take relief from this Miſs Auguſta, yet I'll try and get the reward from Mounſeer. For, if I was to preach in a pulpit as high as Patrick's ſteeple, the ladies, and gentlemen, would be running after one another, and, till they give roaſt beef for nothing, to mere honeſty, a guinea is convenient in an empty pocket.

div.head: SCENE I.—Samphire hall: Sir Hans's, and other Houſes:—A view of the Sea, bathing Machines, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: A month ſince i've been down here at my favourite rocks. How do the lodging-houſes go on? I hope they keep low with their prices, till the place is known. Aye! I may yet ſee Samphire-Hall, eclipſe Brighton, Weymouth, and Scarborough.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Yez! your honour; for the young Squire has ſet up a ſtaple commodity of trade, and already the volks bes ſo merry about'n. You know Humphry Grin, the ſtone maſon, is famous in the letter cutting way—Meaſter George had gin the freedom of the quarry, and he has eſtabliſhed a manufacture for tombſtones.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Tomb-ſtones to make people merry!

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p:
He has finiſhed half a dozen choice epitaphs with:
Afflictions zore
Long time I bore,
Phyſicians were in wain.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Devil's in his phyſicians!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: That was certainly Lord Torrendel turn'd into the green lane—muffled up, and ſeem'd hiding his face. Robin gave me a hint of his deſigns upon Fanny.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: A ſweet morning concert for the rooms, of chipping and ſawing! Tell Maſter Grin, he muſt depart in peace with his merry monuments, from this part of the world. Did you hire a new poſtillion?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Yez, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans. (Seeing George.)
sp.p: Don't come near me—get a tin pot and a bit of ſtick, and pick up cockles on the beach—you haven't a ſoul above a cockle-gatherer, you curſed otter. Robin! have they put up the ſhelves in the raffling ſhop?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Sir, the men are working at their looms.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Looms!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Inſtead of encouraging frauds, cheating ſtrangers with paltry toys, I have erected looms, that will give bread to two induſtrious families.

sp.speaker: Sir. Hans.
sp.p: Why, they're Weavers!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, weavers of ſtockings, gloves, and mittins.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: A ſtocking loom in the place of my elegant raffling ſhop!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: There's a ribband loom too. This was the firſt wove in it; for the motto's ſake, put it in your hat.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans. (reads)
sp.p:
"Succeſs to Commerce, and laſting happineſs to England." Well, let Induſtry throw the ſhuttle to this motto with all
my heart. What ſmoke's that yonder? clinking of hammers! by the lord it's—

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, it's the forge I built for poor old Grimes.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: What, a ſmith?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, a worthy blackſmith.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Within the very walls of my cold bath, old Grimes blowing his bellows!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What uſe for a cold bath juſt on the verge of the ocean? and the farmers want the neceſſary tools for bleſſed agriculture.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: I baniſh you for ever, from my faſhionable bathing place. You barbarous young ſavage! after my high puff advertiſements of cold larders, neat wines, circulating libraries, baths, concerts, balls, billiards, machines, and bathing-caps, to expect to drag people of faſhion down here, amongſt ſtocking-looms, tombſtones, and bellows-clinkers!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Father, my little colony was famiſhing on Lord Torrendel's iſland. Since I have brought them here, in pity don't diſturb them.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: A fine ragged colony you've planted.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Conſider, Father, induſtry is a flower that ſhould be encouraged by the genial warmth of patronage.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: By the lord! the fellow's only fit for a plowman, or a weaver.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Well, Sir, the one gives bread, the other cloathing; as a plowman and a weaver are the moſt uſeful characters, I know of none more noble.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p:
Ah plague on it don't talk to me, my very ſervants will deſpiſe you you dog, I
dare ſay not one of 'em would ſtir a ſtump to ſave your ſoul and body, you young Beaver.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Your purſe, Sir—I found it on the road.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Thank you, Robin,

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: George's purſe! how much was in it?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: More than I can tell—once I knew it to be maſter George's, I never put finger on the caſh it held.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Suppoſe it had been my purſe?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Ecod! your honor, you might never have ſeen it again: Gold's a tempting thing, and I don't ſet up for more honeſty than my neighbours; but young Squire's money already belongs to the poor, and he bez a bad man indeed that wou'd take, what the generous heart is ſo ready to give.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Eh, now Robin, you've been playing tricks, knocking my purſe about—its all broke —ſtupid fellow, I dare ſay you'd take better care of your own!

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: La, Sir, I have no purſe, only a little bit of a leather bag, to divide a few ſhillings from the halfpence.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Whole, and ſound, ſhou'dn't have thought of your impudence—tearing one's property—there's my broken one, I ſhall keep yours.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: But, Sir, the gold's in it.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Never mind, keep it Robin, you're
an honeſt fellow; honeſty is a true diamond, and ſhould be ſet in gold.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: My generous boy, George, build up and pull down, juſt as you pleaſe; (in rapture) the rich man's ſafeſt guard, is the bleſſings of charity; but gold is the grand ſtaple of your trade of benevolence—I've brought Miſs Woodbine, and her fortune; go and entertain her.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Iſn't that Lord Torrendel's Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Your honor, Mounſeer's come from his Lord, to borrow your poſt-chay—going on a viſit, and his own be broke.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Here's an oportunity to oblige my Lord. He ſhall have it, and hanſel my new poſtillion too.

sp.speaker: George. (aſide)
sp.p: Some knavery in this poſtchaiſe! Robin, a word.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Here ſtill; hop to the Lady, you curſt curlew! hold, here ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: 'Twas certainly Arthur croſſ'd the road. (aſide.) Sir, I've walk'd out, to ſee your charming place here.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Hem!—I bid him ſpeak to the Lady, and by the lord he's whiſpering Robin; George, addreſs her with rapture.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, Sir! Madam, the—great—pleaſure of—Robin.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: The great pleaſure of—Robin! oh! the devil's in you, for a fine amorous ſcoundrel! Stop, you Sir.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: This young gentleman is an unadorned caſket, encloſing the moſt delicate ſprings of ſenſibility; but that heart is not for me; or rather mine is not for him. I muſt not cheriſh an hopeleſs paſſion for Arthur; if, as Sir Hans tells me, another poſſeſſes his affections.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: My dear governeſs, I've got down to you; I'm only come, becauſe you are here— where's George?

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: You only come becauſe I'm here— "where's George!" Ah, Fanny!

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I've made papa bring me too—by a monſtrous fib though. I've told him, Sir Hans wants him on moſt prodigious buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Diſtanced the nabber! my lovely partner! who could expect to find you here, like a ſea-nymph ſent from old Neptune's palace, to make mortals plunge into the ocean, enamoured from this divine ſpecimen of aquatic beauty.

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: Moſt heroically gallant indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Now for ſomething gallant to me— How d'ye do, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Ah! little titmouſe, ſuppoſe, my love, you ſtep and gather a few honeyſuckles from the hedge yonder.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: George might have had the manners to meet, and make nymphs of other people. Titmouſe, indeed!

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Madam, you ſee before you, a fellow the moſt wretched— (aſide) ſhall I venture to declare my love? no—farewell.

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: Whither, Sir, are you going?

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: The truth is, Madam, tho' Great-Britain's large, I'm drove to the water's edge, where I'll ſtep into, and puſh off the firſt fiſhing boat I can find; for abandon'd by my father, and purſued by—England, Madam, is no home for me. If I can get acroſs the channel, amongſt camps, and batteries, my empty ſconce may keep a bullet from a head that has brains in it.

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: Your fortunes, Sir, are not, perhaps, ſo deſperate—your mother was—

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: How! Madam, have you heard?— ſhe is I hope an angel—and you my heaven.

sp.speaker: Coachman.
sp.p: Overtaken you at laſt!

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: I'll be damn'd if you have though.

sp.speaker: Coachman.
sp.p: I'll be damn'd but I will though!

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: Unhappy youth! they'll purſue him to deſpair; but I'm uſurping a concern that belongs to the miſtreſs of his heart; yet, tho' I muſt not love, am I to reject all feelings of humanity.

sp.speaker: Fanny. (joyful)
sp.p: Oh! governeſs, I have aſked the poſtillion to give us a roll on the beach—you don't know half this ſweet place.

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: In the chaiſe I may have a better chance of ſeeing which way he takes.

sp.speaker: Fanny. (aſide)
sp.p: Muſtn't tell 'twas my Lord's valet propoſed our ride, ſhe's ſo ſqueamiſh.

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: Does Sir Hans know of this jaunt?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Very true—he may not let us go; I have if, ſit in the chaiſe till I come; I'll fetch your hat and cloak.

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: Is this prudent, but no time for reflection, Arthur may be loſt for ever.

div.head: SCENE II.—A parlour in Sir HANS'S.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: Deviliſh good place the Knight has got here; a fine proſpect of the ſea; a pretty mortgage; and I may pick up ſuch a bit as this, with Torrendel's intereſt—what can this be, Sir Hans has ſent for me!

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: My Governeſs is ſo giddy—where can ſhe have leſt her hat.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: Oh, Fanny, where's your friend Auguſta? you ſeem all upon the fidgets.

sp.speaker: Fanny. (confuſed)
sp.p: Oh no, Sir.—Lud! the two old boys will be running after us—what can I think of to keep them here? oh, true, my fine fib. (aſide) Papa, I wonder why Sir Hans has ſent for you; do you know?

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: No, child, but I ſhall if I can get to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Here he is, ha, ha, ha! (aſide) only look papa, what a fine proſpect at that window; you can ſee, I believe, to the Iſle of Wight.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: Oh no; but very fine.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Fanny, where's your papa?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: He's there, Sir, but his head is ſo full of this ſerious affair, he's come down to tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Oh, very well.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: He, he, he; now each will be ſo full of expectation of the other telling, when there is nothing to tell, it may bring them into a ſquabble, and that will keep them as cloſe as a game of backgammon—but deuce, where's Auguſta's hat? he, he, he.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Ah, Dickins! how do you do?

sp.speaker: Dickins. (turning)
sp.p: Oh, Sir Hans, well, I've trundled down to you in a whiff.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Then the affair is very urgent? ſit down.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: Of conſequence, I hope; for I had 2 good deal to do.

sp.speaker: Sir Haus.
sp.p: And ſo?

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: Well

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Well? ſo ſudden, I was alarmed? but does it concern me ſo much?

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: That you beſt know.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: How the Devil ſhould I know!

sp.speaker: Dickins. (peeviſh)
sp.p: Well then, when you tell me, perhaps I may know.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: When you tell me, perhaps I may not know. But come.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: Ave?

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: The fellow's afraid of being overheard I ſuppoſe; come, I'll faſten the door.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: Oh, if it is of ſo much conſequence, and ſecrecy, I'll faſten this door too. (both riſe and go to oppoſite doors) There now, we are quite ſafe. (ſits down.) aye?

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Aye?

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: What the devil do you fit gaping! why don't you out with it?

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Why do you ſit ſtaring and ſtretching your neck? why don't you tell it at once?

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: You ſent for me down about your buſineſs—and, zounds! what is it? that I may go about mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: I ſend for you! you came here to tell me of ſomething of great importance—tell it, and ſhorten your viſit, when you pleaſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: Sir, your ill manners, in your own houſe, are equal to your impudence in bringing me into it for nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Impudence, you vulgar man! it's well you are in my houſe, or, by the hand of this body, I'd have you pitched out of window.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: Pitch me, you hard-headed old fool! if Torrendel was to behave ſo, I'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: I ſhall choak.— (rings) You're under my roof, you pleb—ſo ſay what you will— Robin Hoofs!

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: Damn your hoofs, and your horns, Sir! I can quit your houſe myſelf. You're as impudent as Torrendel.

div.stage: Enter FANNY, crying, with Auguſta's hat.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p:
Oh George! George! my Governeſs has run away with George! falſe fellow! to
dreſs himſelf up as the new poſtillion, and drive off with my Governeſs, when I only turned to fetch her hat and cloak.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: My ſon drive off with Auguſta! Huzza! he's a daſher.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: And then Lord Torrendel's valet, to jump up behind the chaiſe—'twas all a packd thing to deceive me.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: What! zounds! the Frenchman gone off with my ward.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Yes, they'll ſurely be married.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: What, the Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: No! George! (peeviſh) Did I know where, i'd ſtand up in the church, and forbid the banns.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: But where are they gone?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Rattled down the beach, towards Sandgate Iſland.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Zounds! Robin Hoofs, John, the devil, I've loſt my ward.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Yes, I heard Sir Hans brought her down here to marry George; a demure looking thing, ſhe new better than to take the mad Lord, and I, myſelf to introduce her to my George; this is female friendſhip indeed, here's my friend's hat, and my friend's ribbands, oh that I had herſelf here.

div.head: SCENE III; and laſt.—Sandgate Iſtland; one ſhattered houſe, and a few wretched cottages.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p:
Damn the ferryman, not to run his boat boldly in the creek—oblige me to daſh
through the water! If I could but get over to the continent, I'd fight like a true volunteer—the firſt Enſign that dropt, pick up his colours— huzza! I wiſh I had a ſew ſhillings, to pay my paſſage in ſome fiſhing ſmack.

div.p: There again—by heavens! you ſha'n't have all the bailiff-work to yourſelf—we'll have a tuſsle for it—if you are ſtronger, I go—if not, I commit your body to maſter ſhark—begone, or into this ſea I daſh you.

sp.speaker: Coachman.
sp.p: Then, there Sir, is a three hundred pound Bank of England note—now I've at laſt done my job.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur. (picking it up)
sp.p: It is—and I to miſtake my bright angel for the blackeſt of all imps, a catchpole! three hundred! now they ſhall ſee who is Lord Arthur D'Aumerle—who from? my kind father, doubtleſs. Now I've caſh, where is my poor faithful Timolin.

div.p: A dreary Iſland, but one houſe—you live yonder, maſter.

sp.speaker: Robinſon.
sp.p: Live! ah, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord Ar.
sp.p:
Complain! Why, in the winter here, you've ſtorms in high perfection—ſnow, hail, rain, lightning and thunder, neat as imported —no door to your houſe, and ſcarce a houſe to your door! the ſpangled canopy your bed-teſters, and for a clear proſpect no glaſs to your windows! not a tree on your iſland, becauſe you wou'd not harbour noiſy rooks to diſcompoſe
your ſlumbers!—nor even a buſh! but that's vanity—that you might have it to ſay, you challenge the globe round to ſhew a ſpot more deſolate.

sp.speaker: Robinſon.
sp.p: Why, ſir, but for the charity of Mr. George Burgeſs we ſhould be worſe. He has unpeopled our iſland tho', and ſettled them comfortably near his father's. Since Lord Torrendel, our landlord, leaves us to his Frenchman and that Maſter Dickins, I wiſh they'd take the houſe off my hands.

sp.speaker: Lord Ar.
sp.p: They'll be taking it preſently from about your ears— (aſide.) Ha! ha! ha! I'm tickled with a ſtrange ambition—I'll be king of this Iſland from my father's ſole inheritance. Old Cruſoe, I'll enchant your houſe from the court of poverty, to the caſtle of comfort.

sp.speaker: Robinſon.
sp.p: You look comfort in you happy face. Welcome, ſir, Dame!

sp.speaker: Lord Ar.
sp.p: This iſland is now my territory— here am I king! oh! for my queen! but plague of my palace.

sp.speaker: L'oeil.
sp.p: Now dat your comrade has brought lady over in toder boat, let no one elſe croſs but Milor. (Exit Boatman.) Ah! quel bonheur to find Auguſta myſelf! now Monſieur Thomas and dat villain Iriſh thief may hunt her for deir own recreation—la voice—dis ſolitary iſle—here milor have no perſon to interrupt.—

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p:
The deſire of ſeeing my couſin Arthur once again, before it is too late, can ſcarcely
reconcile me to this ſtep—altogether this iſland wears a moſt forbidding aſpect—I'll return, and ſit in the chaiſe, till Fanny comes.

sp.speaker: Loeil.
sp.p: Ah! ma chere (preventing her.) You muſt vait for Milor.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: He here! heavens! I'm betrayed—I ſee my folly.

sp.speaker: Loeillet.
sp.p: I was your laquais, mon ange, and did ſit behind de chaiſe, and you did not know.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, ſuffer me to go.

sp.speaker: Loeil.
sp.p: Oui, to Londres! dere Milor vill buy you fine cloaths and jewels, and you vill ſhine at operas and ball and concert, and he will kiſs your hand dus.

sp.speaker: Lord Ar.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: L'oeil.
sp.p: Diantre!
sp.stage: (runs off. Lord Arthur purſues. A plunge, as if in water, is heard.)

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Heavens! ſir, what have you done?

sp.speaker: Lord Ar.
sp.p: Only caſt my bait into the ſea— Lucifer will always bite at a ſcoundrel.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Sir, he'll be drowned.

sp.speaker: Lord Ar.
sp.p: A ſouſe, madam! he's already a pickled dog—don't be alarm'd—you're ſafe now from even the ſhadow of inſult. How came you here in this remote place with that ſcoundrel? ſpeak—but no matter—you ſeem diſtreſs'd.

sp.speaker: Aug. (aſide.)
sp.p: Vice ſhould not humble the father in the opinion of the ſon.

sp.speaker: Lord Ar.
sp.p: Lean upon me, ma'am—holloo! old Cruſoe, where's your dame? come, madam.

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: Should Loeillet get my Auguſta ſafe, here is no accommodation; I thought I had ſome tenants on this iſland! they've let the place run ſtrangely to ruin. Confuſion! Sir Hans!

div.stage: Enter Sir HANS, DICKINS, GEORGE and ROBIN, with poſtillions dreſs in hand.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: But dem it ſquire, why diſguiſe yourſelf; ſure you coud'n't be a confederate with that French pandar, to ſteal my daughter's governeſs?

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Aye, George, where was the neceſſity of uſing artifice, to run away with Auguſta, the very girl I wanted to give you.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Then to explain the myſtery—ſome baſe deſigns of others, have ſunk me into a ſchemer of ſtratagems. My lord, my name is Burgeſs.—I'm no profeſs'd knight-errant, yet I openly avow that I will endeavour henceforth to protect female innocence from your lordſhip's diſhonourable purpoſes.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Bravo! George. He has been drinking hock wich Lord Arthur.—My lord, I'll talk to you.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: My lord, to you I'll talk.

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: Then no ſhelter from open ſhame, but to turn champion myſelf! beſides, the ſtorm once blown over, my ſeeming her protector wins her love by gratitude.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Oh, my lord, here flies the ſweet creature, with her character under her arm.

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: That villain, Loeillet, make my ſon's ſervant a party in this buſineſs.

div.stage: Enter Lady TORRENDEL, veiled, and THOMAS.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: Where's my guardian? how!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Aye, I told you, but you wou'd run headlong 〈◊〉 the devil. And there he ſtands, ready to receive you.

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: What's your purpoſe, you ſcoundrels, in bringing the lady to this lonely place?

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Our purpoſe! well, that's very high!—

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: Madam, rely upon my protection. I am bound by honour to defend you from every inſult.

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: Certainly, my lord! every gentleman ſhould be the protector of his wife.

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: Lady Torrendel! damnation!

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: The Lady herſelf! then 'twas to her huſband ſhe was running, oh! here's a wonder, and a blunder!

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p:
My Lord, I ſee you are confounded, yet could I hope your preſent humiliation proceeded from a ſorrow that promiſed repentance, and conſequent reformation, my heart's feelings for the man I did love and honor, ſhould melt me to compaſſion! (weeps) but no! my lord! take
my reſentment! my deſerved, and bitter reproach! grief cannot reach a breaſt ſo callous as yours! it is only the ſtings of a wounded pride, and diſappointed purpoſe, that now agitates you; reflect! return an humble gratitude to heaven for having made my unexpected arrival here the means of ſnatching you from the repetition of a crime the moſt hoſtile to ſociety. A ſelfiſh, tranſient gratification, that muſt baniſh for ever an unhappy female from the paths of honor! ſhun'd thro' life by the beſt part of her own ſex! —and even deſpiſed by you! the author of her ſhame! your wrongs to me are nothing, but your meditated ſhifts, tricks, and plans, which you call gallantries, reflect only a diſgrace on the dignity of manhood!

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: Lady Torrendel—I confeſs I'm altogether ſomewhat ſhocked, and wiſh—I ſay —I'm very unhappy to ſee—that is—I'm unhappy at your ſuſpecting—

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: Oh, you miſtake, my lord! I have no ſuſpicions! mine are all certainties—but even if you conſider my throwing the paſt into the ſhade of oblivion, any indulgence, I ſhall inſiſt upon a few conditions, and the firſt—turn your countenance and protection to that poor deſerted youth! you are, as a parent, reſponſible for every violation that your neglect has occaſioned him to make on the laws of propriety; if you refuſe, I will be his parent, and I henceforth regard your poor friendleſs ſon, with all the care and tenderneſs of maternal affection.

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: He too, a witneſs!

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Huzza, the joy that laughs on me, ſhall ſmile on all around; ſir, I thank you for your bounty, but—

sp.speaker: Coachman.
sp.p: My lady, I gave Lord Arthur the money, and—

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: Well! well!

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: How! from you, madam.

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: Did you give countenance and relief, where wives, in general, look with contempt and even hatred. Madam, can you pardon?

sp.speaker: Lady Tor.
sp.p: My lord, your conduct renders you rather an object of pity, than reſentment—you have implicitly delivered up your fortune, your character, nay more, my lord, your honor, to be the ſport and property of an infamous paraſite— your confidential ſavourite, your French Valet, has counteracted the rectitude of your intentions, by embezzelling the ſums he had for purpoſes dictated by duty and nature. O! why will thoſe who poſſeſs the godlike power of doing good, delegate a baſe, unworthy agent, for the kind purpoſes of ſoft humanity.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Then, madam, 'twas you that relieved me. You're an angel—angel you ſhall ſee! where's my divine Auguſta?

div.stage: Enter Sir HANS, DICKINS, GEORGE, AUGUSTA, and TIMOLIN.

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Here, boy, take Auguſta,

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur. (advancing.)
sp.p: Thank ye, Sir Hans!

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Thank ye, indeed, for that! George, devils in you! will you loſe your wife ſo?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I've one ready at hand—father, with your leave and her own conſent.

div.stage: Enter FANNY, TIMOLIN ſneaks in at the back.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: To be ſure, I conſent—and we all conſent.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Oh! yes! we all conſent—my dear governeſs, are you going to be married? It ſeems I'm going to be married. He! he! he! eh! George?

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: To ſee my ſon taken before my face with an, he! he! he! s'blood, ſir! let the girl go, he, he, he, indeed.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: Then I diſcover your tricks, ſir, oh! oh! oh! indeed!—madam, no matter what he ſays—you are ſtill heireſs to your uncle Woodbine's fortune. Throw it into my bank, chuſe me your guardian, I'll recover—dem'me, I'll ſend Sir Nob a ſheet of cracklin ramſkin, that ſhall reach from Chancery-lane, to the "devil and bag of nails, at Chelſea."

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: Can this be!

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: Indeed! well, even ſo the property of the mother ſhould devolve to the ſon, to him I reſign it.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: No! ſooner than take it from you, my generous couſin, Timolin and I will buffet the world again—where are you, old Bagatrot Caſile?

sp.speaker: Timclin.
sp.p: I'm here, your honour, dead or alive—we'll jump into our boots, before they're bought—and pull juſtice's wigs about—away, maſter! I'm your man thro' thick and thin, fire and ſmoke.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: I could force myſelf to accept this fortune—that is, with a certain ſweet'ner,— Will you, my Auguſta, accompany it?

sp.speaker: Auguſta.
sp.p: Then, ſir, for paltry gold, you'd quit your love! oh! fie!

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Devil's in you, child! I was only joking about the girl over the hock, to make you marry George.

sp.speaker: Lord Tor.
sp.p: Why, this is right. Lady Torrendel, your unexampled liberality will reclaim me into a huſband and a father—my boy, were bleſſings mine, you ſhould have one from me.

sp.speaker: Timolin.
sp.p: Then, as you're not worth a bleſſing, ſhow'r a bundle of yellow-boys upon us both.

sp.speaker: Dickins.
sp.p: A good motion throw them into my bank.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: My lord, father, and you moſt adored Auguſta, if I am deſtined to affluence, here is my model, (to George.) who can forego the comforts of life to beſtow its neceſſaries on the indigent!

sp.speaker: Sir Hans.
sp.p: Why, zounds! my moſt magnificent, gay Arthur, I thought you was to be George's model, and that he'd have grace enough like you to play the devil.

sp.speaker: Lord Arthur.
sp.p: So he ſhall—we'll kick Care out of the window, our abode ſhall be the Houſe of Joy, and the firſt card of invitation ſhall be, to the Man of Sorrow.

q.l: My faults how great! but as no foſt'ring care
Did ever ſmile upon misfortune's heir!
The outcaſt oh receive! your pardon give,
And in your favour, let him happy live!
